segments.pli: Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho āyasmā sāriputto āyasmantaṃ anuruddhaṃ etadavoca:
“asekhenāvuso anuruddha, bhikkhunā katame dhammā upasampajja vihātabbā”ti?
segments.en: “Reverend Anuruddha, what things should a mendicant who is an adept enter and remain in?”

segments.pli: “Asekhenāvuso sāriputta, bhikkhunā cattāro satipaṭṭhānā upasampajja vihātabbā.
segments.en: “Reverend Sāriputta, a mendicant who is an adept should enter and remain in the four kinds of mindfulness meditation.

segments.pli: Idhāvuso, bhikkhu kāye kāyānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ;
segments.en: It’s when a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of the body—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of desire and aversion for the world.
They meditate observing an aspect of feelings …

segments.pli: dhammesu dhammānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ—
segments.en: principles—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of desire and aversion for the world.

segments.pli: asekhenāvuso sāriputta, bhikkhunā ime cattāro satipaṭṭhānā upasampajja vihātabbā”ti.
segments.en: A mendicant who is an adept should enter and remain in these four kinds of mindfulness meditation.”

suttaplex.blurb: Sāriputta and Moggallāna ask Anuruddha what an adept mendicant should practice. He replies that it is the four kinds of mindfulness meditation.
